text: Vesicular Texture Common features of many extrusive rocks are the voids left by gas bubbles that escape as lava solidifies .
Rocks that exhibit a vesicular texture often form in the upper zone of a lava flow , where cooling occurs rapidly enough to preserve the openings produced by the expanding gas bubbles .
If molten rock containing some large crystals moves to a different environment — for example , by erupting at the surface — the remaining liquid portion of the lava cools more quickly .
The resulting rock , which has large crystals embedded in a matrix of smaller crystals , is said to have a porphyritic texture .
Rapid cooling of this type may generate rocks having a glassy texture .
The inset photo is a close-up showing the vesicular texture of hardened lava .
The larger image shows a lava flow on Hawaii ’s Kilauea volcano .
The large crystals in porphyritic rocks are referred to as phenocrysts ( pheno 5 show , cryst 5 crystal ) , whereas the matrix of smaller crystals is called termed a porphyry .
These nearly spherical openings are called vesicles , and the rocks that contain them are said to have a vesicular texture .

However , when a basaltic lava flow enters the ocean , its surface is quenched rapidly enough to form a thin , glassy skin .
By contrast , basaltic magma , which is low in silica , forms very fluid lavas that , upon cooling , usually generate fine-grained crystalline rocks .

Because different minerals crystallize under different environmental conditions ( temperatures and pressure ) , it is possible for crystals of one mineral to become quite large before others even begin to form .
Magmas with high silica content tend to form long , chainlike structures ( polymers ) before crystallization is complete .
During some volcanic eruptions , molten rock is ejected into the atmosphere , where it is quenched ( very quickly cooled ) to become a solid .
So , granitic magma , which is rich in silica , may be extruded as an extremely viscous mass that eventually solidifies to form obsidian .
